moves.3. d5 Bb4+ 4. Bd2 Qe7 5. Nc3: I know I'd have to exchange my dsb, but... too bad. It has some positive sides, too. So I better develop, by castling.
moves.5... O-O 6. a3 Bxc3 7. Bxc3 Ne4: Now, it's foreseeable he'll put his B on b4, and I'll shield my Q with d6, a natural move. But I have a little surprise for him, that already takes him "away from his preparation". Or so I think.
moves.8. Bb4 Qf6: White has to take care of the mate threat.
moves.9. f3: Probably a blunder. Nf3 would have been enough.
He declines my R on f8, and he has no hopes to trap my queen. Or so I trust.
moves.14. Kf2: Kd2 would have been more sensible.
moves.14... hxg4 15. fxg4: Bxg4 doesn't give me enough to go on with the attack (Qd3 or Bg2 could have helped white in releasing the tension). So...
moves.16... f4: Now ideas as Qg3+ are possible... and the N is still in danger.
moves.17. Bg2 Qh2 18. Qh1: White looks for revenge. If I play wrongly, I'll get in trouble along the h column. I better don't allow g6.
moves.18... Qg3+ 19. Kf1 f3: I'd note my second ! on this pawn advance. It is crushing because of e5-e4 coming next.
moves.20. exf3 e4 21. f4 Bxh3 22. Qxh3 Rxf4+ 2: I have "extremely undeveloped +8 points", so... the game is far from won, I can still blow it.
moves.27. Kh2 Nd7: I can't help Re1, but I can take g5, so I better spend a tempo developing.
moves.29. Re1 Qxg5 30. Rxe4 Rf2: How will white defend g2 now? I spotted this when proposing the R exchange. (Thanks "my favourite tactic trainer, I owe you one!")
moves.31. Re8+ Kf7 32. Re2: This move is a resignation. Some points for my rating, and a fun game I didn't... threw away for a blunder. Thanks for reading!
